1357310777.resolved_title: The Man Who Designed Ghost Armies and Opera Houses
1357310777.excerpt: The storied career of the centenarian and acoustician, Leo Beranek. The most celebrated and maligned living acoustician, Leo Leroy Beranek, now 101 years old, has had a storied career.

2.caption: No Feedback: The United Nations General Assembly Hall in the U.N. Headquarters in New York City. Because the podium and its microphones were placed directly in front of audio speakers, an engineering solution needed to be derived to avoid feedback and ringing.

3.caption: The acoustician: Leo Beranek in Westwood, Massachusetts this summer.

4.caption: Muzzled: The auditorium of the Philharmonic Hall in Lincoln Center as viewed from the stage in September of 1962. While Beranek was blamed for the shortfallings in the acoustics, his original plans were not followed and he ended up being sidelined from the project.

1960621232.given_title: Rough, smooth or deep: why the sound of a voice is multisensory
1960621232.resolved_title: Rough, smooth or deep: why the sound of a voice is multisensory
1960621232.excerpt: To make sense of human voices, we rely on senses beyond hearing. The songs of Taylor Swift can be sweet and soft. Lady Gaga’s singing feels dark. Johnny Cash’s voice was low and rough. That’s because voice is not just sound: it can be seen and heard, but also tasted and touched.
